{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3152402,"name":"julian.stevo.clark@gmail.com","username":"Fanatic571","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/e274bd/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-02-25T04:41:28.658Z","cooked":"

We are trying to use a constant torque retractor but when we put a constant force spring it fails and bends the springs. What springs should we use, we found contorque springs but they don’t have the right one off the shelf. Thanks!
Our spring we use: McMaster-Carr

Our mechanism:

image1170×1487 117 KB

Example mexhanism: McMaster-Carr

From the looks of it there is probably a very specific type of CF spring it uses to spool off one spool and onto the other for the McMaster version.

Most of the CF springs I have seen in FRC are only designed to spiral one direction

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2023-02-25T05:39:45.964Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":120,"readers_count":119,"score":29.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":428042,"topic_slug":"constant-force-springs-not-working-in-constant-torque-retractor","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":57536,"username":"Fanatic571","name":"julian.stevo.clark@gmail.com","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/e274bd/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/constant-force-springs-not-working-in-constant-torque-retractor/428042/5","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3152449,"name":"2582","username":"chadr03","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/chadr03/{size}/195529_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-25T06:08:44.973Z","cooked":"

if the geometry lets you it might be possible to separate out your spools and attach some dyneema string or something similar to the end of the spring and that could wrap around your second spool while the spring just pulls straight out.

These? These are not the same as a constant force spring (I think).

Screenshot_20230225-010700864×1920 384 KB

Not only that but there are warnings about bending the spring too much for constant force springs.

Screenshot_20230225-010954864×1920 320 KB

Reverse bending will yield a standard constant force spring. That will ruin their function and fatigue them out.
You need a different type of spring. It will be much thinner…
